text:
+1 on writing for the niche you know to break in. I'm working for an e-commerce SaaS brand right now and I'd absolutely consider a writer who built a store and knows everything ecommerce and just needs an editor and maybe some strong briefs to work off. 

Also, I may be off base here but my gut instinct is that you'll be more likely to get a chance with a mature content org that has the editors and systems in place to polish writing. When I talk to friends on larger teams, it seems like there is always more failsafes on the writing than there are on the SME details. You could bring really valuable expertise to catch the nuance that other writers might miss.

text: A great way to build up your portfolio is to take something from a big brand and make it better. then walk through your choices and what you did to improve it. This is also common in the design world so I’m sure you’re aware of the practice, but it can be easily applied to content as well

This is also common in the design world so I’m sure you’re aware of the practice, but it can be easily applied to content as well

text: Great! Yes, I am familiar with that concept and I have done that in the past. I will start researching this and get to work on those kinds of projects. Thanks!

elements.text: Great! Yes, I am familiar with that concept and I have done that in the past. I will start researching this and get to work on those kinds of projects. Thanks!

text: It's normal in cybersecurity. I have a ghostwriter who writes my client's blog, and then we attribute these pieces to various members of the executive team, who get to review them before they're posted in their names. Same thing at another client where I am the ghostwriter for my client's blog. Having said that, executives often write their own pieces for their own bylines, but companies fall back on ghostwriting as a means to ensure consistent articles. Hope that helps!
